raw_text:
Russian film wins BBC world prize
 
 Russian drama The Return (Vozvrashchenie) has been named winner of the BBC Four World Cinema Award.
 
 The film tells the story of two adolescent boys who are subjected to a harsh regime when their strict father returns after a 10-year absence. Directed by Andrey Zvyagintsev, The Return previously won the 2003 Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival. The prize was presented at an awards ceremony held in London on Thursday and hosted by Jonathan Ross. The winner was chosen by a panel which included X Files actress Gillian Anderson, critic Roger Clarke and Touching the Void director Kevin McDonald.
 
 Ross, who is the presenter of BBC One's Film 2005, was also involved in the deliberations. A shortlist of six films from around the world had been drawn up from which the panel chose. Other nominees included the Motorcycle Diaries, Zatoichi and Hero. A viewer poll saw director Zhang Yimou's martial arts epic Hero emerge as the favourite with 32% of votes cast. Tragedy struck the production of The Return when one of the young stars, 15-year-old Vladimir Girin, drowned in a lake. The winner of the World Cinema Award last year was the French animated feature Belleville Rendezvous
llama3.2:1b: Russian film "The Return" wins BBC Four's World Cinema Award with director Andrey Zvyagintsev.
It tells the story of two adolescent boys subjected to a harsh regime after their father returns from 10 years abroad.
The award was presented by Jonathan Ross, hosted by Gillian Anderson and Roger Clarke.

Vladimir Girin, a star in the drama, drowned in a lake during filming.

smollm:1.7b: The Russian drama "Return" (Vozvrashchenie) has been named winner of the BBC Four World Cinema Award for its outstanding performance and direction.
The film tells the story of two adolescent boys who are subjected to a harsh regime when their strict father returns after a 10-year absence.
Directed by Andrey Zvyagintsev, "Return" premiered at the Venice Film Festival in 2003 and won the Golden Lion award for Best Foreign Language Film.
The winner was chosen by a panel which included X Files actress Gillian Anderson, critic Roger Clarke and Touching the Void director Kevin McDonald.
The BBC Four World Cinema Award is one of the most prestigious awards in the film industry, recognizing outstanding performances, direction, and production values from around the world.
The winners are announced annually at an awards ceremony held in London on Thursday evening.
A shortlist of six films from around the world had been drawn up from which the panel chose.
Other nominees included the Motorcycle Diaries, Zatoichi and Hero.
The winner of the World Cinema Award last year was the French animated feature Belleville Rendezvous (2015).
The film tells the story of a young woman who discovers her family's dark past when she inherits a mysterious mansion from a distant relative.
The winner of the Best Foreign Language Film award was chosen by a panel which included X-Men actress Brie Larson, director Alfonso Cuarón and producer Richard Donner.
